    WoodburyMatrices.SymWoodbury — Type.

    Represents a matrix of the form A + BDBᵀ.

    WoodburyMatrices.Woodbury — Type.

    W = Woodbury(A, U, C, V) creates a matrix W identical to A + U*C*V whose inverse will be calculated using the Woodbury matrix identity.

    WoodburyMatrices.WoodburyMatrices

    WoodburyMatrices.liftFactor — Function.
    liftFactor(A)

    More stable version of inv(A). Returns a function which computs the inverse on evaluation, i.e. liftFactor(A)(x) is the same as inv(A)*x.

    WoodburyMatrices.liftFactorVars
    WoodburyMatrices.partialInv — Function.
    partialInv(O)

    Get the factors (X,Z) in W + XZXᵀ where W + XZXᵀ = inv( A + BDBᵀ )

    WoodburyMatrices.plusBDBtx!
    WoodburyMatrices.sparse_factors — Function.

    Given a type T, an integer n and m tuples of the form (i, j, v), build sparse matrices rows, vals, cols such that the product out = rows * vals * cols is equivalent to:

    out = zeros(T, n, n)

for (i, j, v) in args
    out[i, j] = v
end

    The first two components (i and j) of each tuple should be integers whereas the third component should be of type T

    Example:

    julia> r, v, c = WoodburyMatrices.sparse_factors(Float64, 3,
                                                 (1, 1, 2.0),
                                                 (2, 2, 3.0),
                                                 (3, 3, 4.0));

julia> r*c*v - Diagonal([2.0, 3.0, 4.0])
3x3 sparse matrix with 0 Float64 entries:
    WoodburyMatrices.square
